article.title: Wolf-Rayet spin at low metallicity and its implication for Black Hole formation channels

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements best describes the overall findings from the polarization spectra of Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars in the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) presented in Figure 1?
choices: A majority of the SMC WR stars show clear and strong line effects.
Line effects are present in several SMC WR stars, with the strongest effect observed in SMC-WR3.
SMC-WR8 exhibits a clear line effect characterized by consistent PA excursions coinciding with Stokes I line emission wavelengths.
Line effects are rare amongst SMC WR stars, with only the WR/LBV star HD 5980 showing a firm detection.

multiple_choice_question.text: What distinguishes the spectropolarimetric data of HD 5980 presented in Figure 2 from the majority of other SMC WR stars analyzed in this study?
choices: HD 5980 shows no evidence of polarization, indicating a perfectly spherical stellar wind.
The polarization spectrum of HD 5980 reveals a strong, consistent increase in polarization percentage towards longer wavelengths.
Unlike most other SMC WR stars, HD 5980 exhibits clear line effects, specifically depolarizations, across several strong Helium emission lines.
HD 5980 displays a unique polarization signature characterized by rapid and irregular fluctuations in both polarization percentage and position angle across the spectrum.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figures 3 and 4 present the polarization spectra of a larger sample of WR stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC). What is the key observation regarding the incidence of line effects in this LMC WR sample?
choices: The incidence of line effects is significantly higher in the LMC WR sample compared to the Galactic WR sample, supporting the rotation-induced CHE model.
Line effects are predominantly observed in WC-type WR stars within the LMC sample, suggesting a potential link between carbon-rich WR stars and rapid rotation.
The LMC WR sample shows a similar, relatively low incidence of line effects (~10%) as the Galactic WR sample, challenging the assumption of increased rapid rotators at lower metallicity.
Line effects in the LMC WR sample are exclusively detected in WN-type stars, suggesting a strong correlation between nitrogen-rich WR stars and enhanced rotation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Table 2 lists stellar parameters for WN stars exhibiting line effects. What trend can be observed when comparing the terminal wind velocities (v) of LMC Ofpe/WN9 stars (BAT99-22 and BAT99-33) to those of Galactic WN8 stars (WR 16 and WR 40)?
choices: LMC Ofpe/WN9 stars have significantly faster wind velocities (v > 1000 km/s) compared to Galactic WN8 stars (v < 700 km/s).
The terminal wind velocities of both LMC Ofpe/WN9 stars and Galactic WN8 stars are similar and relatively low (v â‰ˆ 400 - 650 km/s).
Both groups of stars show a wide range of terminal wind velocities, with no discernible trend or correlation.
Galactic WN8 stars consistently have slower wind velocities (v < 100 km/s) compared to the much faster LMC Ofpe/WN9 stars (v > 1000 km/s).
